content.question: A GRAPHING CALCULATOR IS REQUIRED FOR THIS QUESTION. You are permitted to use your calculator to solve an equation, find the derivative of a function at a point, or calculate the value of a definite integral. However, you must clearly indicate the setup of your question, namely the equation, function, or integral you are using. If you use other built-in features or programs, you must show the mathematical steps necessary to produce your results. Your work must be expressed in standard mathematical notation rather than calculator syntax. Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit. Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point. Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> for which <math alttext="f of x"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> is a real number. Gwen runs back and forth along a straight track. During the time interval <math alttext="0 is less than or equal to t, is less than or equal to 45"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>45</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> seconds, Gwen’s velocity, in feet per second, is modeled by the function <math alttext="v"><mstyle><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> given by <math alttext="v of t, equals, the fraction with numerator 250 times the sine of, open parenthesis, the fraction with numerator t squared, and denominator 120, close parenthesis, and denominator t plus 6, end fraction"><mstyle><mrow><mi>v</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>250</mn><mi>sin</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mfrac><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow><mrow><mn>120</mn></mrow></mfrac><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>6</mn></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math>. (a) What is the first time, <math alttext="t sub 1"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, that Gwen changes direction? Find Gwen’s average velocity over the time interval <math alttext="0 is less than or equal to t, is less than or equal to t sub 1"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>.

frqParts.text: A GRAPHING CALCULATOR IS REQUIRED FOR THIS QUESTION. You are permitted to use your calculator to solve an equation, find the derivative of a function at a point, or calculate the value of a definite integral. However, you must clearly indicate the setup of your question, namely the equation, function, or integral you are using. If you use other built-in features or programs, you must show the mathematical steps necessary to produce your results. Your work must be expressed in standard mathematical notation rather than calculator syntax. Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit. Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point. Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> for which <math alttext="f of x"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> is a real number. Gwen runs back and forth along a straight track. During the time interval <math alttext="0 is less than or equal to t, is less than or equal to 45"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>45</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> seconds, Gwen’s velocity, in feet per second, is modeled by the function <math alttext="v"><mstyle><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> given by <math alttext="v of t, equals, the fraction with numerator 250 times the sine of, open parenthesis, the fraction with numerator t squared, and denominator 120, close parenthesis, and denominator t plus 6, end fraction"><mstyle><mrow><mi>v</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>250</mn><mi>sin</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mfrac><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow><mrow><mn>120</mn></mrow></mfrac><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>6</mn></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math>. (a) What is the first time, <math alttext="t sub 1"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, that Gwen changes direction? Find Gwen’s average velocity over the time interval <math alttext="0 is less than or equal to t, is less than or equal to t sub 1"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(b) At time <math alttext="t equals 45"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>45</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, how far is Gwen from her position at time <math alttext="t equals 0"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> ?

(c) Find the total distance that Gwen runs during the 45 seconds from time <math alttext="t equals 0"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> to time <math alttext="t equals 45"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>45</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(d) Let <math alttext="a, of t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>a</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> represent Gwen’s acceleration during the time interval <math alttext="0 is less than t, is less than 45"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo><</mo><mi>t</mi><mo><</mo><mn>45</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> seconds. Find the value of <math alttext="the integral from, 15 to 30, of, a, of t, d t"><mrow><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mrow><mstyle><mrow><msubsup><mrow><mo>∫</mo></mrow><mrow><mn>15</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>30</mn></mrow></msubsup><mrow><mi>a</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></mrow></math>. Using correct units, explain the meaning of <math alttext="the integral from, 15 to 30, of, a, of t, d t"><mrow><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mrow><mstyle><mrow><msubsup><mrow><mo>∫</mo></mrow><mrow><mn>15</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>30</mn></mrow></msubsup><mrow><mi>a</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></mrow></math> in the context of the problem.

topic.text: 8.1: Finding the Average Value of a Function on an Interval

skill.text: Skill 1.D: Identify an appropriate mathematical rule or procedure based on the relationship between concepts (e.g., rate of change and accumulation) or processes (e.g., differentiation and its inverse process, anti-differentiation) to solve problems.
